content: The report discusses key base closure developments from the 105th to the 107th Congress, including the signing of legislation in December 2001 for a new base closure round in 2005. The closures and realignments from previous BRAC commissions have resulted in significant savings. Defense spending trends and force structure changes have necessitated additional base closures. The Department of Defense began advocating for more base closures in 1997 with the release of the Quadrennial Defense Review by Secretary William Cohen. He emphasized the need for further closures to align infrastructure with force structure reductions and achieve significant cost savings for future readiness and weapons programs. Secretary of Defense Cohen proposed new rounds of base closures to fund future readiness and weapons acquisition programs. However, there was resistance from Capitol Hill due to concerns about economic and political fallout in their districts. Despite initial pushback, some Senators pledged to push for more base closings to reduce excess infrastructure and secure funds for new weapons.
